channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: New Pussy Riot Video Asks Where Russia’s Oil Wealth Goes
item.description: In a new song released online Tuesday, the Russian protest group Pussy Riot claims that billions of dollars of the nation’s oil wealth have been looted by President Vladimir V. Putin and his allies.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A member of the Russian protest group Pussy Riot throws oil on a portrait of Alexander Bastrykin, a senior law-enforcement official, known for harassing groups critical of the president.

item.title: India Ink: 21 Children Die From Poisoned Lunches at Indian School
item.description: The children complained that the food tasted odd, and after seeing the students get sick, teachers and administrators fled the school.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A man holding the body of his daughter inside an ambulance in Patna, India, on Wednesday. Twenty-one children died after eating a free midday meal at a primary school in Bihar State.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Literary Critic and Novelist Shamsur Rahman Faruqi
item.description: Literary critic Shamsur Rahman Faruqi speaks about his debut novel, British colonialism, and Indian history.
item.dc:creator: By SONAL SHAH
item.media:description: Shamsur Rahman Faruqi, an Urdu literary critic and author of the book "The Mirror of Beauty."

item.title: Letter from India: Delhi Metro Reaches Across Class Lines
item.description: The subway system is one of the few places in India where an iPad-toting professional squeezes in next to a housemaid. It is also one of the rare government projects the public genuinely loves.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: China Detains a Leading Human Rights Advocate
item.description: Xu Zhiyong, who was held Tuesday on unlawful assembly charges, has challenged the Communist Party to act on its vows to expose corruption and respect the rule of law.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Assad Supporter Killed by Gunmen in Southern Lebanon
item.description: Mohamed Dirrar Jammo, a prominent Syrian commentator and staunch defender of the government of President Bashar al-Assad, was gunned down Wednesday at his home.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Putin Does Not Expect Ties With U.S. to Be Harmed by Snowden Case
item.description: President Vladmir V. Putin said Wednesday that bilateral relations were more important than the controversy surrounding Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Zhengzhou Journal: The Demanding Off-Hour Escapes of China’s High-Tech Workers
item.description: Young people who work making iPhones and other electronic devices in China flock to nightclubs in their time off, desperately trying to enjoy the present as they strive for a better future.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of young Chinese come to the city of Zhengzhou to work in electronics factories. To escape the monotony of the assembly line, many take up roller skating as a hobby, like at the outdoor roller rink.

item.title: China: Four Officials Detained Over Mine Explosions
item.description: Four local officials are being investigated for “dereliction of duty” in two coal mine blasts that killed 53 people last spring.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Guinea: Gas Station Theft Ignites Deadly Ethnic Clashes
item.description: At least 16 people have been burned alive or hacked to death with machetes, and dozens wounded, during two days of ethnic clashes in the south.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gay Marriage Law Is Approved by Parliament
item.description: Gay marriage is to become legal in England and Wales after the lower house of Parliament approved the final changes to a law that had the backing of Prime Minister David Cameron.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Algeria: Ailing Leader Returns
item.description: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika returned home on Tuesday after 80 days of treatment in France for a stroke.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Bomb Strikes Hezbollah Convoy Near Syria
item.description: A convoy carrying members of the Shiite militant group Hezbollah was hit by a roadside bomb near Syria’s border, killing one and wounding two, officials said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Under Pressure, Bangladesh Adopts New Labor Law
item.description: Lawmakers amended the law three weeks after the United States announced plans to suspend Bangladesh’s trade privileges over labor rights and safety violations in factories.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

item.title: Capture of Mexican Crime Boss Appears to End a Brutal Chapter
item.description: With the arrest of the feared Zeta crime boss Miguel Ángel Treviño Morales, Mexico’s long and bloody drug war may have reached a crossroads.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and GINGER THOMPSON
item.media:description: Mourners in Guatemala City in March 2012, at the coffin of one of 193 bodies found in 26 mass graves in northern Mexico the year before. Guatemalan migrants were among the dead.

item.title: Sudan’s President One Step Ahead of a Suit and a Warrant
item.description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan left an African Union meeting in Nigeria after human rights groups filed a suit calling for his arrest on a warrant accusing him of genocide.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan at an African Union summit meeting Monday. He is wanted on a warrant charging him with genocide.

item.title: Panama Seizes Korean Ship, and Sugar-Coated Arms Parts
item.description: A freighter on its way from Cuba to North Korea was found carrying missile-system components cloaked in a cargo of sugar, the Panamanian authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The North Korean-flagged cargo ship Chong Chon Gang docked at a pier in Colon, Panama, on Tuesday.

item.title: Egypt’s New Government Doesn’t Include Muslim Brotherhood
item.description: The cabinet, which was praised by some for its diversity, replaces the government of Mohamed Morsi, a Brotherhood member who was deposed nearly two weeks ago.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: A supporter of former President Mohamed Morsi in Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: Leaker Files for Asylum to Remain in Russia
item.description: Edward J. Snowden submitted an application that seemed aimed at insulating President Vladimir V. Putin from United States pressure and blame.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: The President of Venezuela Weds His ‘First Combatant’
item.description: After resisting formally tying the knot for about two decades, President Nicolás Maduro and Cilia Flores were married on Monday, Mr. Maduro announced.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: The Lede: Images of Latest Deadly Clashes in Cairo
item.description: Images and video posted online by reporters and witnesses offered detailed views of clashes late Monday around a train station in central Cairo.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: His Ship Still Aground, Captain Goes on Trial
item.description: Francesco Schettino, accused of abandoning his ship after it ran aground and capsized off the Tuscan coast, could face up to 20 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: The Costa Concordia last week. A risky effort to right the ship, which capsized off the Tuscan coast last year, is set for September. One Italian official wants it delayed. Residents say the wreck has crushed the local economy.

item.title: 2 Japanese Airlines Report No Problems With 787
item.description: All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines said emergency checks on their Boeing 787s turned up no threats after a fire last week in a 787 parked at Heathrow Airport.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and CHRISTOPHER DREW

item.title: Ruins in a Center of Syria’s Uprising
item.description: After a year of siege, the city of Homs in central Syria may well be the site of the most concentrated destruction in the country.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: In Homs, Syria, several central areas have been gradually destroyed as they have changed hands several times between the Syrian rebels and the army.

item.title: The Lede: Prominent Gay Rights Activist Is Found Dead in Cameroon
item.description: Eric Ohena Lembembe was found dead in his home in Yaoundé, shortly after he wrote about attacks on organizations that support gay rights. Cameroon is one of 38 African countries that criminalize homosexuality.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER
